title: Décor at Gracie Mansion Now Fits de Blasio’s Style

abstract: Smaller cities are increasingly attractive for New York chefs, who find savvy audiences willing to support innovative restaurants.
author: By REBECCA FLINT MARX
copyright: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
title: Chefs Move Beyond New York

abstract: The apparent online recruitment of four Indian Muslims to join the fight in Iraq has shocked their home country, which had believed that it was immune from such defections.
author: By ELLEN BARRY and MANSI CHOKSI
copyright: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
title: 4 Young Men Head for Iraq, Citing Fight for Islam, and India Wonders if More Will Follow

abstract: Four decades ago the near-impeachment of Richard Nixon rocked the nation. Several books and television programs are reviewing his presidency and its scandals.
author: By PETER BAKER
title: 40 Years Later, Still Trying to Define Presidential Power

abstract: It's no wonder we're the country of favelas, and houses of cardboard and tin.
author: By VANESSA BARBARA
title: Brazil's Unaffordable Homes

abstract: Visitors from all over are lining up at the Louvre, the Vatican and the Uffizi museums, posing problems for institutions trying to balance accessibility with art preservation.
author: By RACHEL DONADIO
copyright: Guia Besana for The New York Times
title: Masterworks vs. the Masses

abstract: Mr. Roberts, who has been in the Senate since 1997, defeated Milton Wolf, a radiologist and hard-line conservative, in a closely watched Republican primary.
author: By JONATHAN WEISMAN
copyright: Chris Neal/Topeka Capital-Journal, via Associated Press
title: Senator Pat Roberts Beats Tea Party Challenger in Kansas

abstract: The Filipino menu at Lumpia Shack Snackbar in the West Village takes a step up from the food market.

abstract: Battles with insurance companies usually end with the same score: Health Insurer 1, Patient 0. This story of a multiple sclerosis patient seeking an experimental treatment is different.
author: By DAVID SEGAL
title: Dogged Persistence Pays Off, With Interest

abstract: Thirteen months after he was released from prison, the former baseball All-Star leapt from topic to topic in an interview, making clear his wish for another chance at credibility and wealth.
author: By RICHARD SANDOMIR
title: Lenny Dykstra: Out of Prison, and Still Headstrong

abstract: Industry executives are now acknowledging that the escalating tensions could sharply hurt companies with major investments in Russia.
author: By STANLEY REED
title: Energy Companies Rethinking Russia After New Round of Sanctions

abstract: Ram V. Sutar, one of the worlds most prolific sculptors, braces for the possibility of his most gigantic commission yet.
author: By GARDINER HARRIS
copyright: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
title: An Indian Sculptor With Monumental Ambition

abstract: The 36-year-old network is making a broad effort to discover, develop and disseminate shows for children who barely distinguish among a television set, a laptop, a tablet and a mobile phone.

title: Nickelodeons Digital Generation

abstract: Experts are urging people to overcome their hesitation and discuss with their heirs the plans for allocating assets.
author: By PAUL SULLIVAN
copyright: Nathan Weber for The New York Times
title: Whats Almost as Certain as Death? Not Talking About the Inheritance

abstract: The tennis star Caroline Wozniacki, who was planning a November wedding with the golfer Rory McIlroy until he broke off their engagement, will run in New York on Nov. 2.
author: By MARY PILON
title: Wozniacki Is Lining Up for New York Marathon

abstract: Cambridge University has digitized 4,100 handwritten pages of notes by the British wartime poet Siegfried Sassoon and has made them available free online.

abstract: Analysis of satellite imagery taken before and after the first two and a half weeks of the Israeli incursion.

title: Assessing the Damage and Destruction in Gaza

abstract: Racing to secure space to accommodate 53,000 full-day prekindergarten seats, New York City is asking religious schools to house more public school students.
author: By SHARON OTTERMAN
title: De Blasios Prekindergarten Expansion Collides With Church-State Divide

abstract: Mr. Post was a public radio personality known for mocking himself, his employers, his sponsors and the conventions of broadcasting.
author: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
title: Steve Post, Sardonic Wit on WNYC, Is Dead at 70

abstract: Life for about 200,000 people packed into more than 80 schools serving as shelters in Gaza is full of deprivation and discomfort.

copyright: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
title: School Shelters in Gaza Offer Limited Safety, and Even Less Comfort

abstract: The strange little documentary Nixon by Nixon: In His Own Words, which airs Monday on HBO, alternates a public persona with a closeted monster revealed by secret White House tapes.

abstract: The Tribune Companys publishing unit, including eight well-known newspapers, will venture forth as an independent entity in troubled times, led by Jack Griffin.
author: By CHRISTINE HAUGHNEY

abstract: As domestic consumption falls, Japanese brewers are trying to increase exports, even going abroad to find the right pairings with Western cuisine.

copyright: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
title: Sake With Your Burger? Japan Is Looking West to Save a Tradition

abstract: The league receives global exposure through such play but gets few tangible benefits, and team owners worry about injuries to players they have invested a lot of money in.

abstract: To combat the anti-immigrant sentiment in Sweden, a young teacher has begun hosting communal dinners to help bridge the gap between cultures.

abstract: The state party has been increasing its use of modeling, which takes voter registration and history information to target likely supporters.

abstract: The number of veterans chopped from the roster of the World Series champion Boston Red Sox is staggering.

abstract: A lack of funding for investigators means the real power of the legislation would be the anonymous survey data from students published online.

abstract: The 1966 365 P Berlinetta Speciale, which is heading to auction, is startling in many ways, but its the three-across seating, with the driver in the center, that is its most unusual feature.

abstract: The fight over the three-story boardinghouse made a folk hero of Vera Coking, who became known for fending off eminent domain, Donald J. Trump and his multimillion-dollar offers.

abstract: A comic book property like “Guardians of the Galaxy” may seem ideal for the big screen, but comics have singular pleasures of their own.

abstract: Dine seaside, sip cocktails high above the water or just stretch out in the sand during this coastal weekend in Catalonia.

abstract: When the British tax authorities struck a landmark deal with the Swiss to crack down on tax evasion, they sat back and waited for the cash to flow in. Almost three years later, they are still waiting.
